text:
Plumb Island, looking east from center of the Island. Beyond Plumb Beach Channel is a part of Gerritsen Beach. In the background is the Marine Parkway Bridge.

July 13, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Plumb Island - [Plumb Beach Channel in Brooklyn.]

text:
Barren Island, in Jamaica Bay, Brooklyn. In the background are the hangars and Administration Building of Floyd Bennett Field. View 2 shows also the Marine Parkway Bridge to Rockaway.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: July 4, 1935
View 2: July 24, 1937
title: Islands - Barren Island - [Jamaica Bay - Brooklyn.]

text:
(1)
Plumb Island, south side, eastward to Point Breeze, showing the beach at low tide.

July 7, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the beach only. In the background, beyond the Rockaway Inlet, is Fort Tilden (barn affair).

July 4, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, after clearance by the W.P.A. and prior to improvement as a park. The Marine Parkway Bridge, seen in the background is nearing completion. It will connect the Rockaways with Brooklyn.

April 29, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Plumb Island (South side) - Point Breeze - Brooklyn.

title: Bridges - Marine Parkway Bridge - [Rockaway Inlet.]

text:
crosses Rockaway Inlet bet Brooklyn and Rockaway

Marine Parkway Bridge. 1937.  A vertical lift bridge providing a clearance of 55' in the down position, and 150' in the raised position. The bridge crosses Rockaway inlet between Brooklyn and Rockaway.
title: Bridges - Marine Parkway Bridge - [Rockaway Inlet between Brooklyn and Rockaway.]

text:
Barren Asland showing in a set of three views different sections of the southern end of Barren Island. View No. 1 also shows the Marine Parkway Bridge.

July 24, 1937.

Views 1, 2 and 3

P.L. Sperr, photographer
title: Islands - Barren Island (South).

title: Islands - Barren Island (South).

text:
(1)
Plumb Island: A view eastward towards Marine Park, showing a group of shacks recently demolished by men and fire. It is upon this waste that Marine Park will be constructed.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing a farther view southeastward. Note in the background the new Marine Parkway Bridge which was opened to the public on July 3rd 1937. On the two following days 1,000,000 people went over it.
April 29, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
The same, looking more to the southeast from the north side of Plumb Island. Note the remaining shacks on the eastern part of the Island. Shown indistinctly in the background, looking like a huge barn, is Fort Tilden.
June 18, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.
title: Islands - Plumb Island (East) - Marine Park - Brooklyn.

text:
Rockaway Inlet, in a set of two views, showing sections of the Marine Parkway Bridge and the slips of the New York City ferry that plied between Brooklyn and Rockaway, now discontinued.

July 24, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Rockaway Inlet - Queens - [Marine Parkway Bridge - New York City ferry.]

text:

July 24, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Rockaway Inlet - Queens - [Marine Parkway Bridge - New York City ferry.]

text:
Marine Parkway Bridge 1937. A vertical lift bridge providing a clearance of 55' in the down position, and 150' in the raised position. The bridge crosses Rockaway inlet between Brooklyn & Rockaway.
